awd_titl_txt: CC* Networking Infrastructure: A High-Performance Science DMZ and Dedicated Research Network for Duquesne University
awd_abstract_narration:
Duquesne University is implementing a dedicated research network and Science DMZ for the facilitation of science-driven research, education and collaboration. A vibrant and growing Duquesne research community conducts leading edge research and scientific experimentation in a broad range of science domains. The campus network is unable to support the data-intensive workflows generated by the research community. While science drivers and research workflows vary, there is a common need for fast and unrestricted data movement to internal and external research computing resources. The research-focused Science DMZ cyberinfrastructure addresses the limitations of the general purpose network by establishing a dedicated, scalable and secure network that is optimized for data-intensive science workflows. 
 
The project objective is to establish a dedicated 120Gbps Science DMZ network to support the Duquesne research community. A critical element of the Science DMZ is a Data Transfer Node (DTN). The DTN will provide University researchers with a secure, highly-available, high-performance data exchange point to facilitate the secure and efficient sharing of research data with collaborating institutions and national computational research facilities. The Science DMZ will connect to a dedicated 10Gbps uplink to the Pennsylvania-wide education and research computing network (KINBER).
 
The new friction-free cyberinfrastructure not only accelerates large scale data movement, it facilitates new and more efficient workflows resulting in the acceleration and advancement of scientific discovery. The research network improves opportunities to train the next generation of research scientists and to inspire underrepresented groups to participate in scientific research activities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: DUQUESNE UNIVERSITY OF THE HOLY SPIRIT

por.por_cntn:
What was accomplished under these goals and objectives?

Major Activities:

  • Developing our staff in understanding the unique requirements, architectures, and other associated details of research infrastructure, big data transport, and overall cyberinfrastructure capabilities in support of research
  • Designing, procuring, and installing the research network / science DMZ
  • Establishing a service model to provide and support research infrastructure services to the research community
  • Supporting, and fostering awareness within, the research community in leveraging this infrastructure for their research and to best position them to achieve research grants
  • Establishing a Research Computing Advisory Committee (RCAC) to accomplish the above and aid in the governance of, and priorities for, this infrastructure

Specific Objectives:

  • University research capabilities - Enhance the University's ability to support academic research, particularly that requiring the high-speed transport of "big data" (large data sets)
  • University staff development - Learning how to architect, build, and support said infrastructure in support of the research community
  • Future opportunities - Better positioning the University to achieve future grants towards improving/growing our research infrastructure and ultimately contributing to global problem-solving.

Significant Results:

  • Built our science DMZ.
  • Established a service model.
  • Collaborated with researchers on leveraging this infrastructure/service.
  • Established (a draft charter for) the RCAC.

Key Outcomes and Achievements:

  • Learned both technical and operational requirements for building and managing such infrastructure.
  • Supported various research endeavors and better positioned the university to both achieve research grants and conduct research requiring such infrastructure.
  • Created an extensible, research infrastructure foundation.
  • Better positioned the University to achieve future grants towards improving/growing our research infrastructure and ultimately contributing to global problem-solving (e.g., biomedical imaging data transport, AI-based graphical recognition and labeling, large survey data set transport and analytics, and transport, analytics, and storage of large research data sets broadly).
  • These Labs are currently being built in Mellon Hall for the College of Osteopathic Medicine specifically for research using the Science DMZ Network:
    • Lab B4
      • PI: Dr Alicia Morgan
      • Research area: Biomedical, bone biology
    • Lab 312
      • PI: Dr Kassim Traore
      • Research area: Biomedical, biochemistry/toxicology
    • Lab 318
      • PIs: Drs. Delbert Abi-Abdallah; Crystal Boudreaux; Yanfei Qi
      • Research area: Biomedical, microbiology/immunology
    • Lab 221
      • PI: Dr Yunbo Li
      • Research area: Biomedical, pharmacology/toxicology
    • Lab 230
      • PI: Dr Hong Zhu
      • Research area: Biomedical, pathophysiology
  • Beyond the NSF grant, we have been able to explore extending connections to the science DMZ via separate trunk ports on other, production, edge switches.
  • As we have built out high-speed transport, we have now been able to come to the realization that storage is the next deficiency in our overall research infrastructure and have begun exploring options for big-data storage.

What opportunities for training and professional development has the project provided?

  • Network engineers were able to attend training on science DMZ architectures.
  • Network engineers were able to attend training on Data Transfer Nodes and their function.
  • Network engineers were able to (people) network with both the University research community and broader research community.
  • Network engineers were ultimately able to design, build, and manage the resulting research infrastructure.
  • Various IT staff were ultimately able to develop a service model for deploying, extending, and supporting this infrastructure.
  • Leadership was able to integrate more directly with researchers across the institution on research infrastructure needs and governance.

Have the results been disseminated to communities of interest?

Yes, (some) results have been disseminated to (some) communities of interest.  The aforementioned overall results of the grant have been communicated with many among the University's research community, including, of course, the Office of Research and Innovation, and the aforementioned RCAC is being (re-)constituted to further disseminate the results of the grant and our new research infrastructure capabilities to the broader University research community.  Specifically, though, we have had outreach with everyone from the Office of Research and Innovation to Physical Sciences to Nursing to Health Sciences to the Department of Math and Computer Science to Libraries/Archives to Environmental Engineering to Osteopathic Medicine.

Additionally, our leadership has been asked to serve on the Advisory Committee for KeystoneREN's PA-Science-DMZ and has accepted.  This represents a strategic opportunity to connect to the recently-NSF-funded statewide DMZ once established.



Service Catalog - Research Computing

https://services.duq.edu/TDClient/30/Portal/Requests/ServiceCatalog?CategoryID=9

por.por_txt_cntn:
What was accomplished under these goals and objectives?


Major Activities:

Developing our staff in understanding the unique requirements, architectures, and other associated details of research infrastructure, big data transport, and overall cyberinfrastructure capabilities in support of research
Designing, procuring, and installing the research network / science DMZ
Establishing a service model to provide and support research infrastructure services to the research community
Supporting, and fostering awareness within, the research community in leveraging this infrastructure for their research and to best position them to achieve research grants
Establishing a Research Computing Advisory Committee (RCAC) to accomplish the above and aid in the governance of, and priorities for, this infrastructure



Specific Objectives:

University research capabilities - Enhance the University's ability to support academic research, particularly that requiring the high-speed transport of "big data" (large data sets)
University staff development - Learning how to architect, build, and support said infrastructure in support of the research community
Future opportunities - Better positioning the University to achieve future grants towards improving/growing our research infrastructure and ultimately contributing to global problem-solving.



Significant Results:

Built our science DMZ.
Established a service model.
Collaborated with researchers on leveraging this infrastructure/service.
Established (a draft charter for) the RCAC.



Key Outcomes and Achievements:

Learned both technical and operational requirements for building and managing such infrastructure.
Supported various research endeavors and better positioned the university to both achieve research grants and conduct research requiring such infrastructure.
Created an extensible, research infrastructure foundation.
Better positioned the University to achieve future grants towards improving/growing our research infrastructure and ultimately contributing to global problem-solving (e.g., biomedical imaging data transport, AI-based graphical recognition and labeling, large survey data set transport and analytics, and transport, analytics, and storage of large research data sets broadly).
These Labs are currently being built in Mellon Hall for the College of Osteopathic Medicine specifically for research using the Science DMZ Network:  

Lab B4  

PI: Dr Alicia Morgan
Research area: Biomedical, bone biology


Lab 312  

PI: Dr Kassim Traore
Research area: Biomedical, biochemistry/toxicology


Lab 318  

PIs: Drs. Delbert Abi-Abdallah; Crystal Boudreaux; Yanfei Qi
Research area: Biomedical, microbiology/immunology


Lab 221  

PI: Dr Yunbo Li
Research area: Biomedical, pharmacology/toxicology


Lab 230  

PI: Dr Hong Zhu
Research area: Biomedical, pathophysiology




Beyond the NSF grant, we have been able to explore extending connections to the science DMZ via separate trunk ports on other, production, edge switches.
As we have built out high-speed transport, we have now been able to come to the realization that storage is the next deficiency in our overall research infrastructure and have begun exploring options for big-data storage.



What opportunities for training and professional development has the project provided?

Network engineers were able to attend training on science DMZ architectures.
Network engineers were able to attend training on Data Transfer Nodes and their function.
Network engineers were able to (people) network with both the University research community and broader research community.
Network engineers were ultimately able to design, build, and manage the resulting research infrastructure.
Various IT staff were ultimately able to develop a service model for deploying, extending, and supporting this infrastructure.
Leadership was able to integrate more directly with researchers across the institution on research infrastructure needs and governance.



Have the results been disseminated to communities of interest?


Yes, (some) results have been disseminated to (some) communities of interest. The aforementioned overall results of the grant have been communicated with many among the University's research community, including, of course, the Office of Research and Innovation, and the aforementioned RCAC is being (re-)constituted to further disseminate the results of the grant and our new research infrastructure capabilities to the broader University research community. Specifically, though, we have had outreach with everyone from the Office of Research and Innovation to Physical Sciences to Nursing to Health Sciences to the Department of Math and Computer Science to Libraries/Archives to Environmental Engineering to Osteopathic Medicine.


Additionally, our leadership has been asked to serve on the Advisory Committee for KeystoneREN's PA-Science-DMZ and has accepted. This represents a strategic opportunity to connect to the recently-NSF-funded statewide DMZ once established.
